question.text: During Searle's experiment, zero of the Vernier scale lies between <math><mn>3.20</mn><mo>×</mo><msup><mrow><mn>10</mn></mrow><mrow><mo>-</mo><mn>2</mn></mrow></msup><mi mathvariant="normal"> </mi><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi></math> and <math><mn>3.25</mn><mo>×</mo><msup><mrow><mn>10</mn></mrow><mrow><mo>-</mo><mn>2</mn></mrow></msup><mi mathvariant="normal"> </mi><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi></math> of the main scale. The <math><msup><mrow><mn>20</mn></mrow><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">t</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">h</mi></mrow></msup></math> division of the Vernier scale exactly coincides with one of the main scale divisions. When an additional load of 2 kg is applied to the wire, the zero of the Vernier scale still lies between <math><mn>3.20</mn><mo>×</mo><msup><mrow><mn>10</mn></mrow><mrow><mo>-</mo><mn>2</mn><mi mathvariant="normal"> </mi></mrow></msup><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi></math> and <math><mn>3.25</mn><mo>×</mo><msup><mrow><mn>10</mn></mrow><mrow><mo>-</mo><mn>2</mn></mrow></msup><mi mathvariant="normal"> </mi><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi></math> of the main scale but now the <math><msup><mrow><mn>45</mn></mrow><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">t</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">h</mi></mrow></msup></math> division of Vernier scale coincides with one of the main scale divisions. The length of the thin metallic wire is 2 m and its cross-sectional area is <math><mn>8</mn><mo>×</mo><msup><mrow><mn>10</mn></mrow><mrow><mo>-</mo><mn>7</mn></mrow></msup><mi mathvariant="normal"> </mi><msup><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msup></math> . The least count of the Vernier scale is <math><mn>1.0</mn><mo>×</mo><mi mathvariant="normal"> </mi><msup><mrow><mn>10</mn></mrow><mrow><mo>-</mo><mn>5</mn></mrow></msup><mi mathvariant="normal"> </mi><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi></math> . The maximum percentage error in the Young's modulus of the wire is

solution.text:
Y=FLlA since the experiment measures only change in the length of wire
∴∆YY×100=∆ll×100
From the observation l1=MSR+20 LC
l2=MSR+45LC
⇒ change in lengths =25LC
and the maximum permissible error in elongation is one LC
∴∆YY×100=LC25LC×100=4
